title: docs: add missing feature for doc gen
Fixing the nrf54l drive configuration bug
body: Fixes a mistake that misconfigures the drive pins for the nrf54l I notice while working on the support for the nrf54l.

title: [STM32G4] Introduce traits for special ADC channels
body:
Not all special channels like Temperature are available on all ADCs and they don't always use the same channel number.

This PR introduces traits that have associated consts for the channels.
The traits are also used as bounds for the functions to create the channels.

This works for H7 as well, but I've implemented the traits for with the same old channels on all ADCs to keep it on par with what previously was. But now at least someone could come in and make it more granular for H7 too.

title: some minor documentation fixes
body: cargo doc threw some errors.. some of them simple to fix, for the others I hopefully corrected them correctly based on the context :) In some cases, there were references to private API

title: add embassy sync channel example for message passing between interrupt and task
executor: mark Spawner::for_current_executor() as unsafe.
body: It's unsound with manually-created Contexts, see https://github.com/embassy-rs/embassy/issues/4379

title: excutor: fix Send unsoundness with `-> impl Future` tasks.
embassy-executor: rtos-trace: fix task naming for new tasks
body: Tasks that are spawned after starting SystemViewer were not named. This change ensures that tasks spawned while SystemViewer is running will be properly named, too.

title: embassy-stm32: Added sample shifting to qspi config
body:
I noticed the sample shifting configuration for the stm32 QSPI driver is missing as `QUADSPI.cr().sshift()` is always set to `false` on initialization [here](https://github.com/embassy-rs/embassy/blob/main/embassy-stm32/src/qspi/mod.rs#L123). 

This PR adds the sample shifting option found in the STM32 CubeIDE to the existing embassy-stm32 QSPI Config.

title: Add note about UART line breaks being different from ASCII
body: I confused myself for a while because I'm working with a GPS module that sends an ASCII line break character (\n) to indicate the end of a transmission. I initially thought `read_to_break` would read until it saw a line break character, but it actually does the (much more sensible) reading until a UART break condition is encountered. This adds that distinction to the docs.

title: stm32: Fix impl embedded_hal_nb::serial::Write for usart::UartTx
body: It fixes `impl embedded_hal_nb::serial::Write for usart::UartTx` because old code calls `blocking_write` in non blocking trait.

title: rp: add current_core api
body: This PR adds a new API within the embassy-rp multicore module to get which core the code is currently executing on. This is similar to functionality already present in the embassy-stm32 crate.

title: embassy-nrf: fix PWM loop count
body:
The PWM sequencer offers to run a sequence for a limited time by specifying `SingleSequenceMode::Times(n)` with `n > 0`.

Currently this value is ignored and the loop register is set to `1`.

This PR fixes the behaviour. It has been tested using a NRF9160 in secure mode.

title: Link to esp-generate
body: Some people are trying to use cargo-embassy for our chips and end up disappointed. Let's link to the vendor-supported generator.

title: Use proper RCC clock enable for opamps
body:
OpAmp::new() now resets the opamp and enables its clock. The clock disabled when the opamp is dropped. On families that use SYSCFGEN (F3 and G4), this is not done because clock is always on in Embassy.
    
This change makes use of the RCC driver, which uses a reference counter to prevent conflicts. The opamp itself is still disabled when its output is dropped.

The PR intentionally does not add opamp features for more families yet to make reviewing easier.

The following table shows the opamp clock enable bits for all families, taken from RMs and/or CubeMX generated code:

| Family  | Example     | RCC       |
| ------- | ----------- | --------- |
| L1 (*)  | STM32L152RE | COMPEN    |
| F3      | STM32F303K8 | SYSCFGEN  |
| L4      | STM32L432KC | OPAMPEN   |
| L4+     | STM32L4P5ZG | OPAMPEN   |
| H7      | STM32H755ZI | OPAMPEN   |
| L5      | STM32L552ZE | OPAMPEN   |
| G4      | STM32G474RE | SYSCFGEN  |
| U5      | STM32U545RE | OPAMPEN   |
| H5      | STM32H503RB | OPAMPEN   |
| U0      | STM32U031R8 | OPAMPEN   |
| U3      | STM32U385RG | OPAMPEN   |

(*) L1 OPAMP not yet in stm32-data

title: mspm0: Fix inverted GPIO logic
body: `get_output_level()` was attempting to read the input buffer, which is currently disabled by this HAL when a pin is configured as an `Output`, resulting in a constant logical low reading. After fixing this I noticed that the equivalent input reading logic was inverted. This PR fixes both issues.

title: Minimise build profile tweaking in rp/rp235x examples
body:
To avoid confusion around build profile tweaks (see #4346), remove optimisation/lto changes and just enable generation of debug symbols for release profiles.
Also add a comment explaining that it is intentional so it is less likely to be seen as a mistake in the examples.

title: [stm32h723]: fix spdifrx example
body: The STM32H723 SPDIF RX example was not yet adapted to the new `Peri` API and thus failed to compile. This PR remedies that.

title: [stm32]: Replace per-channel traits in `timer` module with generic versions
Fix Release and Dev Profiles Being Backwards in rp235x Examples
nxp: add feature for lpc55
body: this is needed since I will be working on adding support for the MCX and iMXRT families to embassy-nxp

title: Added STM32WBA6XXX devices as features
body:
Added the following
- new devices (a.k.a. features) from `stm32-data`
- within `ci.sh`: attempt to build 2 `stm32wba6[2|5]` devices
- handled a default rtc implementation if the generated peripherals didn't match the mapping.
- handled a new generated peripheral `rtc_v3c0` recently introduced to `stm32-data-generated`

title: Adapt to new opamp pin naming scheme and opamp IP version numbers
body:
The new code implements the corresponding traits for the common opamp pin naming scheme of all families, which is VINPx/VINMx and adapts the opamp driver to new opamp IP version numbers.

The same pin must not be used for multiple channels for the same opamp. For example, if VINM0 and VINM1 of the same opamp were assigned to the same pin, the channel would not be unique, meaning that the traits would be implemented in a conflicting manner.

title: Correct esp-hal link
body:
Every other link points to the relevant HAL, let's not confuse Espressif users 🙃

This is also my sneaky way to prioritize esp-hal over esp-idf-svc for newcomers.

title: mspm0: add dma driver
body:
Add a DMA driver for mspm0. So far only implement features available on all (basic) channels. copying slices is also not implemented yet nor anything related to source/destination stride. 

~~A few things pending before this is ready to review~~
- [x] merge https://github.com/mspm0-rs/mspm0-data/pull/6
- [x] add tests for u16, u32 and u64 transfers
- [x] ~~Figure out why `TransferMode::Single` with `dst.len() > 2` performs 2 transfers instead of 1 (as expected in datasheet)~~ (likely hardware bug)
- [x] ~~Test multiple triggers (`resume()`)~~
- [x] Remove the settings.json changes (after I am done)

title: STM32H7RS Examples: Add OPI functionality to the XSPI example
body:
- Cleans up the SPI and OPI commands to match the datasheet for the flash used on the Nucleo board
- Creates a separate impl for OPI operations

This has been tested on an STM32H7S3 nucleo board.

Unfortunately, the datasheet for the flash chip used on the nucleo board is not public however I was able to get access to it in order to get this example fixed up to match the datasheet.

title: Allow conditional items in bind_interrupts macro
body:
Resolves #4333 

Fixes a regression that prevented conditional items from being used in the bin_interrupts macro

title: Added STM32 ADCv1 analog watchdog implementation
body:
There is currently no implementation of the analog watchdog (AWD) for any STM32 ADCs in embassy. This adds AWD support to v1 ADCs. The examples should speak for themselves. The tldr is:

1. Configure which pins to monitor and what thresholds to apply using `adc.init_watchdog(pins, low_threshold, high_threshold)`
2. Wait for the watchdog to trip using `adc.monitor_watchdog().await`

title: Add syntax highlighter
body:
This requires installing the [rouge gem](https://docs.asciidoctor.org/asciidoctor/latest/syntax-highlighting/rouge/), but it gives some basic syntax highlighting.

Assuming it already runs fine on your machine prior to this commit, you just need to run `gem install rouge` and add `:source-highlighter: rouge` to `index.adoc`

### Examples:
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/261827cc-777d-4db6-891c-60850814a516)
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e0a595ed-3632-4a4b-a7ec-c7b338c06f2d)



I noticed a couple problems other than this, like the build script complaining about missing files, but seemingly still building fine without images. I did however have to replace this file because it doesn't seem to exist in the repo:

https://github.com/embassy-rs/embassy/blob/206a324cf4d612122356fb350b4a3b56391d6f20/docs/pages/overview.adoc?plain=1#L68C1-L73C1

title: Only write to the flash what was read from the file
body: The write method is given the full aligned buffer to write to flash even though it may not be fully populated. This change ensures only what has been read is written to flash. Preventing potential corrupted firmware and additional flash wear.

title: embassy-stm32: fix HSEM initialization and core detection
body:
The current STM32 HSEM driver is broken on at least one platform I've tried (STM32H755) due to a couple of bugs:

- the peripheral wasn't enabled at the RCC level
- the core ID detection was broken: the match cases are correct, but it's missing a right-shift on the mask

title: embassy-stm32: Rename PWM Input constructors, add warning on usable timer peripherals
body: Some timers don't support PWM Input mode. See below for STM32G4 RM0440: And PWM Input is usable only with CH1 and CH2 on all families.

title: Fix sync bounds on LazyLock and OnceLock
body:
This pull request introduces changes to ensure stricter `Sync` trait implementations for `LazyLock` and `OnceLock` types in the `embassy-sync` crate. It also adds regression tests to verify these changes and prevent incorrect usage of these types with non-`Sync` data. Additionally, a new dependency (`trybuild`) is added for compile-time testing.

### Stricter `Sync` Implementations:

* [`embassy-sync/src/lazy_lock.rs`](diffhunk://#diff-cd31bb3d341607967bd756da8f3d44ab3106dc08d38c7b4ec235230b584c2723L34-R39): Updated the `Sync` implementation for `LazyLock` to require both `T` and `F` to implement `Sync`.
* [`embassy-sync/src/once_lock.rs`](diffhunk://#diff-e8478b2fa15a8e88ebb2d2ea0faecdfc7223d2c3b8c5ccc0ce631aa432d74939L45-R45): Updated the `Sync` implementation for `OnceLock` to require `T` to implement `Sync`.

### Regression Tests for Compile-Time Errors:

* [`embassy-sync/tests/ui.rs`](diffhunk://#diff-b93a33ee71aaf155cb7b6f03478c2859084d60d09bb29b83e108f1b086a32e1fR1-R13): Added compile-fail tests using `trybuild` to ensure `LazyLock` and `OnceLock` do not unconditionally implement `Sync` for non-`Sync` types.
* [`embassy-sync/tests/ui/sync_impl/lazy_lock_function.rs`](diffhunk://#diff-8718c0de6b942640ffb134d6add1b5e573e2841c472cd6be7e5deece2e29a1ecR1-R15): Added a test case where a `LazyLock` is initialized with a closure capturing a non-`Sync` variable, which should fail to compile.
* [`embassy-sync/tests/ui/sync_impl/lazy_lock_type.rs`](diffhunk://#diff-294d2eb1b6946e68e6c4fd888f878c778449d58b7eddaf65770d4838422f484eR1-R6): Added a test case where `LazyLock` is used with a non-`Sync` type (`*mut u8`), which should fail to compile.
* [`embassy-sync/tests/ui/sync_impl/once_lock.rs`](diffhunk://#diff-fd48543eaaf2518651235c829ec4a185716da86bedf3e6f6a3ece260cb9164b9R1-R6): Added a test case where `OnceLock` is used with a non-`Sync` type (`*mut u8`), which should fail to compile.

### Dependency Addition:

* [`embassy-sync/Cargo.toml`](diffhunk://#diff-8ef39bee7253569f3e25944bb7297e3b70d36e6e5308c17c8b0bce9c2cc903f4R46): Added `trybuild` dependency for compile-time testing.

fixes #4307
fixes #3904

title: [sdmmc] Set `datatime` during initialization
body:
I've had the chance to test `embassy-stm32`'s eMMC support on an STM32L562 microcontroller, which works with `#[sdmmc_v2]`. I'm not sure if it's a behavior specific to that or the particular eMMC chip used, but I found that `Sdmmc` initialization would hang after sending the `SWITCH` command (used by `modify_ext_csd`). This is caused by an `R1b`-type response that took longer to clear the busy status than supported by the microcontroller's default timeout configuration. The immediately following `embassy-stm32` code wouldn't check or clear the timeout error flag, so it got stuck waiting for a completion that would never occur.

To solve this I've added a new `set_datatime` call into `init_internal`, prior to any `R1b` commands or datapath transactions. Furthermore, since values written to that register appear to be persistent across datapath transactions, I've removed it from `read_block` and `write_block` altogether (since there's no way to modify the configuration after initialization anyways).

title: embassy-rp: fix rom_data documentation format
body:
This removes the `//!` doc comment markers from the [`rom_data`][rd] module documentation strings, as these appear in the generated output when using the `#[doc(...)]` attribute.

[rd]: https://docs.embassy.dev/embassy-rp/git/rp2040/rom_data/index.html

body:

title: prepare release for `embassy-rp` & dependencies
body:
see the individual commit messages for further details.

what this PR does for the affected crates:
* it adds changelog entries for the new releases
* it adds release automation using [`cargo-release`](https://crates.io/crates/cargo-release)
* it fixes `release/bump-dependency.sh` (inadvertently created backup files, leading to lots of untracked files)

what this PR does *not* do:
* it does *not* run `release/bump-dependency.sh` for the crates (should only be done after the release of each crate)
* it does *not* enter a version number or release date in `CHANGELOG.md` (now taken care of by `cargo-release`)
* it does *not* prepare a new release for `embassy-sync`: while there were already new commits again there was just a release a few days ago so it's probably not yet needed?
* it does *not* add `cargo-release` setup for any other embassy crates. i'm floating this here as a test balloon

suggested flow of this PR for reviewers with commit access to the repo & release rights on crates.io:
1. review & merge the PR
2. install `cargo-release` (`cargo binstall cargo-release`)
3. run the following steps from latest `main` (after the merge) in a clean repo:

```bash
pushd embassy-futures
cargo release patch --execute
popd
# no need for this since it's just a patch: ./release/bump-dependency.sh embassy-futures 0.1.2
# if you do it anyway you should also do this: git commit -am 'update to `embassy-usb` v0.1.2'

pushd embassy-usb-driver
cargo release patch --execute
popd
# no need for this since it's just a patch: ./release/bump-dependency.sh embassy-usb-driver 0.1.1
# if you do it anyway you should also do this: git commit -am 'update to `embassy-usb-driver` v0.1.1'

pushd embassy-net-driver-channel
cargo release minor --execute # or possibly also patch if `embassy-sync` has no impact on the public API & cross-crate compatibility?
popd
./release/bump-dependency.sh embassy-net-driver-channel 0.4.0
git commit -am 'update to `embassy-net-driver-channel` v0.4.0'

# no commit for this in this PR since it has no changelog
pushd embassy-hal-internal
cargo release minor --execute
popd
./release/bump-dependency.sh embassy-hal-internal 0.3.0
git commit -am 'update to `embassy-hal-internal` v0.3.0'

pushd embassy-executor-macros
cargo release minor --execute
popd
./release/bump-dependency.sh embassy-executor-macros 0.7.0
git commit -am 'update to `embassy-executor-macros` v0.7.0'

pushd embassy-executor
cargo release minor --execute
popd
./release/bump-dependency.sh embassy-executor 0.8.0
git commit -am 'update to `embassy-executor` v0.8.0'

pushd embassy-time-driver
cargo release patch --execute
popd
# no need for this since it's just a patch: ./release/bump-dependency.sh embassy-time-driver 0.2.1
# if you do it anyway you should also do this: git commit -am 'update to `embassy-time-driver` v0.2.1'

pushd embassy-time
cargo release patch --execute
popd
# no need for this since it's just a patch: ./release/bump-dependency.sh embassy-time 0.4.1
# if you do it anyway you should also do this: git commit -am 'update to `embassy-time` v0.4.1'

pushd embassy-embedded-hal
cargo release patch --execute
popd
./release/bump-dependency.sh embassy-embedded-hal 0.4.0
git commit -am 'update to `embassy-embedded-hal` v0.4.0'

pushd embassy-rp
cargo release minor --execute
popd
./release/bump-dependency.sh embassy-rp 0.5.0
git commit -am 'update to `embassy-executor-macros` v0.5.0'

git push --tags # push all version commits & tags
```

title: Add public function to get current clock configuration
body:
This PR provides a means for user code to access the current clock configuration, addressing #3909.

We must ensure that the new `rcc::clocks()` function does not allow the user to hold a reference to `CLOCK_FREQS`: (1) before `embassy_stm32::init()`, (2) during `rcc::reinit()`. This is done using references to the `Peri<RCC>` singleton.

Change requests welcome.... I am still wrapping my head around the Peri struct

title: STM32 USB: Read data before register update
body:
Many thanks Dario for finding it!

When using CDC ACM sometimes a packet would contain data of the *next* packet after it.
This seems to solve the issue.

title: Use modify() for subsequent changes to RCC.cr()
body: Should close #3635 , and also fixes an issue where MSIK stops when HSI is enabled.

title: doc: add high-level embassy-boot a-b info
body: For embassy-boot, added some high-level info on how the a-b partitions system works to the prologue of the bootloader section of the embassy book.

title: Fdcan use RAII for reference counting.
Use a critical section mutex in CAN Fdcan driver.
body:
The FDCAN driver was using a static function to hand out &mut State internally. Generally, care was taken to only access this from within a critical section or Interrupt. The interrupt case is an issue, if some code decided to [de]configure the buffering mode from a higher priority interrupt level than the CAN interrupt. This seems unlikely, anyway... 

This change was proposed by @DrTobe in: https://github.com/embassy-rs/embassy/pull/4223

This required: https://github.com/embassy-rs/embassy/pull/4265 as a dependency. Which also points us to the fact that buffered mode was unsound if the Channel was constructed with a Raw mutex. The first commit in this series blocks that.

This patch has been tested on STM32G431 boards, mainly with the buffered mode.

title: feat: add support for channel peek
body: Add support for peeking into the front of the channel if the value implements Clone. This can be useful in single-receiver situations where you don't want to remove the item from the queue until you've successfully processed it.

title: Enable Sync and Send for DynamicSender and DynamicReceiver.
body: DynamicSender and DynamicReceiver, just seem to be a fat pointer to a Channel which is already protected by it's own Mutex already. In fact, you can share the Channel already betwen threads and create Dynamic*er's in the target threads. It should be safe to share the Dynamic*er's directly.

title: stm32: Improvements to CRC HAL.
body:
* Corrects spelling and grammar errors in documentation.

* Removes non-v1 code from v1-only source file.

* Adds 'read' operation for v2/v3, to be consistent with v1.

* Removes 'reset' from the v2/v3 'reconfigure' operation to match the documentation (the only user is the 'new' function which already issues a reset).

title: stm32: Assert in BufferedUart that the buffers are not empty.
body: I struggled using BufferedUart (could not receive any data) and it turned out that the cause was that I was passing empty slices as the buffers... RingBufferedUartRx already has an assertion to catch this (which is how I discovered the issue).

title: stm32: Expand documentation of RingBufferedUartRx.
body:
Explain to users of this driver how 'waiting for bytes' actually works, and what that may mean for latency introduced in their application.

Also correct references to 'start' to be 'start_uart'.

title: executor: Make state implementations and their conditions match
body:
Hi!

I am playing around with embassy on AVR (an ATmega328p) and stumbled into some oddities. There are three implementations of the executor state that are conditionally selected based on the existance of 8-bit atomics. All of them however use 32-bit integers.

Since only 2 bits are actually used, I have modified the non ARM specific ones to use a u8 instead of a u32.  In the case of AVR, there are no 8-bit atomics but using a u8 with a critical section instead of u32 still save around 60-bytes or so in a minimal test.

I might be missing something obvious so feel free to reject the pull request.

body: App core doesn't have a TEMP peripheral.

title: embassy-rp: implement input/output inversion
body: RP2040/RP23xx support inversion in HW of the inputs and outputs. Implement minimal support for that.

title: Support RGBW on PioWs2812
body:
Some ws2812 (aka neopixel) devices have an additional white led. The current pio program does not support these and can cause weird shifting issues due to using only 24 bits on the FIFO config threshold. Add an optional program that supports this white led, and supports using `smart_led::RGBW<u8>`

See [this repository](https://github.com/MatrixSenpai/ripple/blob/6dcf3a26aa6b17bc549177ae20b9e43c298fc95e/binary/src/ws2812/pio.rs#L50-L94) for the original working implementation.

title: Adding documentation to network std examples
body:
I have been getting familiar with networking using the **std examples** and I have put together a comprehensive documentation to guide a user to run the network related std examples.

I have also corrected a the tap.sh file since it looks like the original intention was to give ownership to the `tap99` to the current user but effectively was giving ownership to `root`. This way the examples can be run, and debug, with the unprivileged user credentials.

Please consider adding this changes. to the repository and thanks all the contributors and maintainers!

title: Prepare embassy-sync 0.7
body:

I think this needs a major bump because of the critical-section std change.

If there are other planned pending embassy-sync changes please don't let this rush a release.

title: [embassy-stm32] add PWM multi channel waveform generation using DMA burst mode
body:
This PR adds the waveform_up_multi_channel method, enabling PWM waveform generation using DMA burst transfers triggered by timer update events (UEV).

DMA operates through the DMAR register using configured DBA/DBL to update multiple CCRx registers in one transfer.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8bfc4d04-27ea-4e78-a533-f40d2fafb85b)

title: feat(stm32): provide a `const` constructor on `rcc::Config`
body:
## Description

Currently, the only way of instantiating an `embassy_stm32::rcc::Config` is through the `Default` trait, which makes it not instantiable from `const` contexts.

This PR introduces a `const` `embassy_stm32::rcc::Config::new()` constructor.

## How to review this PR

- This PR is better reviewed commit by commit: each commit targets one STM32 (sub-)family, except for the first one which *also* introduces a `const` constructor for `Hsi48Config` and `LsConfig`. I can easily split that first commit or, on the opposite, squash all this PR's commits into a single one if you prefer.
- Please do check that this PR is complete and that I didn't forget an STM32 family or some feature-gated field. I did do a basic sanity check by grepping for `::default(` in `embassy-stm32/src/rcc` (the remaining seems irrelevant to this PR).

## Issues references

Closes #4213.

title: mspm0: generate interrupt group handlers
body:
No more ugly `#[path]` attributes or manually written code. The only annoying part is that the user must tell rustc to link the `interrupt_group.x` file.

This does require a little linker *magic*, inspired by `cortex-m-rt`. In the future for other things in interrupt groups I'll write an abstraction to allow binding these. When `#[linkage = "extern_weak"]` is promoted to stable then we can have a far nicer setup than this.

GPIO examples work correctly from my testing. (I should write some tests for these soon eh?).

title: mspm0: add gpio handlers to l122x/l110x
body: Dumb mistake pretty much, should fix CI explosions.

title: Cleanup Pins and RCC for FDCAN on STM32
body:
This PR uses the reference counting logic already implemented in the `fdcan` module to also call `set_as_disconnected` on the pins and to possibly disable the RCC clock. Before, only the "buffered" readers and writers have been counted to set the modes back to `NonBuffered` after the last one had been dropped. Now, all readers and writers are counted, a TX _and_ RX type like `Can` or `BufferedCan` counts as both.

This works because there is only one direction to initialize the types: `CanConfigurator` -> `Can` (unbuffered) -> `BufferedCan`/`BufferedCanFd` (-> drop). In other words: Since there is no way to go back from buffered to unbuffered without stealing the peripheral, users should definitely drop the old instance before. So when the last active instance is dropped, the modes are set back to `NonBuffered` and pins and RCC are cleaned up. When a new "peripheral steal" happens, the peripheral should be in the expected (initialization) state.

Additionally, the `CanConfigurator` must already be considered as a writer+reader because it already enables the pins and RCC clock, so it also needs to trigger the cleanup.

But to be honest, I am not 100% satisfied with this implementation because it is not very elegant in several ways:
1. The `NotifyCreated` events must be triggered manually whenever one of the several CAN types ist created, and for every CAN type, a separate `Drop` impl must be supplied (all being nearly identical). And there are many CAN types: `CanConfigurator`, `Can`, `BufferedCan`, `BufferedCanFd`, and the separate `Tx` and `Rx` types (unbuffered and buffered, FD and classic). Instead, I would rather like to implement an RAII guard with a corresponding constructor, `Clone` impl and `Drop` impl and make all CAN types contain the required guard(s). This would be a less error prone implementation.
2. There seems to be some amount of duplication: First, the `SealedInstance` contains `Info`, `Registers` and `internal_operation`, but the `Info` struct contains `Registers` and `internal_operation`, too. Second, `calc_timestamp` is implemented for the `Info` type and for the `SealedInstance`, too. Some of this duplication is caused by the need to work around type erasures, but I guess this could be cleaned up. Specifically, I think we could split all static information into the `Info` and `State` types and make all CAN types contain one `&'static Info` and one `State` reference/pointer. Furthermore, I guess that the `internal_operation` and the `calc_timestamp` implementation can be moved out of or be removed from the `SealedInstance`, respectively.
3. At some places, we reference a `&'static State` which is sometimes mutably accessed via `self.state as *const State as *mut State` followed by a dereference. This may work and seems to be ok if we think about it in terms of pointers and memory addresses, but according to [the Rustonomicon](https://doc.rust-lang.org/nomicon/transmutes.html), transmuting a shared reference to a mutable reference is absolutely forbidden, and that's what we are effectively doing here. So I would suggest to be honest about what we do here and _at least_ use a `*mut State` directly instead of a `&'static State`. The accesses are and need to be unsafe anyways. But even better, why don't we use a `critical_section::Mutex` here?

For now, I have only implemented the naive approach because I would like to get some feedback on the three intended changes first. This is because these seem to be larger changes and I would not like to do all the work without it being merged eventually. So, what do you think about the suggested refactoring? Otherwise, I am also fine with merging this as is, or, we could merge this for now and do the refactoring afterwards. This last approach would be nice because the cleanup feature gets available already and the following refactoring could be split in small(er) parts.

title: timer: ostimer: wait for match write ready
body: Before writing to MATCH_L/MATCH_H registers, wait for permission to do so by pollinmg MATCH_WR_RDY bit in CTRL register.

title: [embassy-usb-dfu] support ed25519 verification
body:
This commit adds the ability to verify that USB DFU updates are correctly signed using ed25519.

This required adding support to embassy-boot for reading from the DFU partition.

The memory map for the `stm32wb-dfu` also had to be adjusted to accommodate the larger bootloader.

title: nrf/rng: add Blocking/Async Mode param.
body:
This allows avoiding creating the irq handler if you're only going
to use it in blocking mode.

title: Add rand-core v0.9 support.
body:
- Implement rand-core v0.9 in HALs (keeping v0.6 support, same as we do with embedded-hal v0.2 and v1.0)
- Add inherent methods
- Switch most examples to use inherent methods instead of rand-core.

title: Fix a minor formatting issue in `README.md`
body: The `**` is in the wrong place.

title: Impl Drop for stm32 Rng
body: This disables the RNG in the CR::RNGEN register and calls `rcc::disable` to possibly disable the corresponding clock if the refcount goes to zero. Using the "low-power" feature, I have verified that this allows to enter STOP2 mode again after the RNG has been dropped.

title: fix: add bank confdiguration doc build features
add the possibility to document `bind_interrupts` `struct`s
body:
the `bind_interrupts` macro creates a `struct` for the interrupts. it was so far not possible to document those (except for STM32) and there was no generic documentation being generated/added either, thus the `missing_docs` lint was triggered for consumers which enabled it.

with this change it is now possible to manually add a comment on the `struct` being defined in the macro invocation.

to show that this works one RP example has been modified accordingly.

title: rp: add missing `Debug` and `defmt::Format` `derive`s for ADC
body: this doesn't cover every `struct` & co. in `embassy-rp`, but at least it adds those needed for `Adc` and `adc::Channel`.

title: nrf: _3v3 -> _3V3
body: typo in Reg*Voltage

title: Update doc comment for adc read to match current implementation
body: The code in the doc comment did not compile due to updates to the function. After this change it now matches the code in the example folder.

title: Interrupt Doc Comments
ci: build std examples on aarch64-unknown-linux-gnu (local)
body: So that when I do local `ci.sh` runs std examples get built on my aarch64-unknown-linux-gnu machine.

title: mspm0: generate features per chip + package
body:
This pull request along with some work on the mspm0-metapac side now allows the `Peripherals` type to only pins that are available for a chip + package combo. This is to match the behavior in embassy-stm32.

All the examples and tests build and run as intended.

`get_chip_cfgs` is a little cursed but that is temporary since I plan to deal with interrupt groups after this.

Regarding feature names, I have chosen to exclude temperature rating so the same feature is used before a standard (`S`) and Q100 qualfied (`Q1`) part. Embassy doesn't care whether your parts on tape & reel or tray, so distribution method is excluded.

For reference:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/2bf4f2b2-52a6-41f1-844d-97cbaec6d512)

Fun fact, there are 128 part numbers for MSPM0 parts. Only 25x less than the STM32. Unfortunately more parts are coming so hopefully TI doesn't catch up soon.

title: embassy-rp: Make bit-depth of I2S PIO program configurable
body:
The `PioI2sOutProgram` had a fixed 16bit sample depth, but that isn't reflected in the types name or the documentation.

The `PioI2sOut` output driver on the other hand accepts a `bit_depth` argument.
This was previously only used to calculate the clock frequency, while no other values than 16 made any sense.

This MR implements setting the sample bit-depth by setting it to scratch register `Y`, from where it is read by the PIO program. 

Also the channel argument is removed, since only 2 channels are supported.

title: [embassy-usb-dfu] support function level WinUSB GUIDs
body: This PR makes it possible to provide function level msos GUIDs to usb_dfu. This helps to ensure that composite DFU devices automatically get assigned the WinUSB driver on Windows.

title: RP235x overclocking
body:
After overclocking for rp2040 got enabled, this adds convenient overclocking for rp235x.

**Maintainer Note**:

Unlike for the rp2040 there is no manufacturer support for running on higher frequency or higher core voltage. Meaning 
 this is out of specs for now and in case this is considered too risky, please do not merge this!

**Reviewer Note**:

+ AI usage only for syntax help on setting registers, rest is hand-rolled
+ Add Core Voltage options for rp235x, add brownout detection values for rp235x
+ Add rp235x branch for this to `init()`
+ Add fn `core_voltage()` to retrieve the value from register instead of reading it from the config and update examples accordingly
+ Add one rp235x example
+ Add test branch for rp235x
+ some documentation changes

title: nrf5340: Add IPC peripheral
body:
This is a heavily reworked version of #3658.

I added the PPI task/event, and made each IPC event its own struct that can be handled independently.

title: Clarify embassy-rp rt feature purpose
body:
The original comment was mostly wrong.
Replaced it a brief explanation and a link to the docs which should hopefully give the user better context.

title: Stm32: Fix opamp copy pasta mistake
body:
The opamp was refactored in #4089 but I think there was a copy paste error.

The old code:
https://github.com/embassy-rs/embassy/blob/d41eeeae79388f219bf6a84e2f7bde9f6b532516/embassy-stm32/src/opamp.rs#L149-L156

When a gain was selected (which is now always true in the new function), the VmSel is 0x10 (PGA). But in the new code it was left on OUTPUT.

I was seeing weird ADC values and this fixes it.

title: embassy-usb-dfu: Modify Reset trait
body:
Modify the `Reset` trait's `reset` function to return `()` instead of `!` and adds a `&self` parameter. This makes it easier to implement cleanup before resetting the whole chip.

I also tacked on a change to reset immediately if `WILL_DETACH` is set, instead of waiting for a USB reset from the host since the WinUSB driver isn't capable of generating this USB reset.

title: Implement embedded-io-async traits for USB CDC ACM
body:
Implement embedded-io-async Read and Write traits for USB CDC ACM.

For the Receiver side, this requires being able to buffer a received packet if the caller doesn't read the entire length in one go, so a separate `BufferedReceiver` is created for this.

title: iMXRT OS timer
body: Let the user select the OS Timer0 as a time source.

title: [embassy-stm32] Derive Debug, Clone, Copy, defmt::Format for simple_pwm::PwmPinConfig
